channel.title: Daily Feed (Updated 9 AM BD)
channel.description: Daily Feed (Updated 9 AM BD) generated by script

item.title: Thai Parliament Dissolves to Head Off No-Confidence Vote
item.description: Triggering snap elections raises the specter of more political turmoil amid deadly clashes with Cambodia.

item.title: What to Make of China’s Trade Surplus
item.description: The imbalance raises questions about the global economy and Trump administration policy.

item.title: Will California try to block Hollywood’s next megadeal?
item.description: States are beefing up their antitrust enforcement

item.title: What in the World?
item.description: Test yourself on the week of Dec. 6: A West African coup fails, violence flares on the Thailand-Cambodia border, and Lithuania declares a state of emergency.

item.title: What Happens to China’s Surplus Men?
item.description: The one-child policy’s gender imbalance has spawned desperate bachelors, dubious gurus, and a rising manosphere.

item.title: The Nvidia Chip Deal Is a National Security Disaster Waiting to Happen
item.description: Trump’s latest proposal would cede the United States’ AI advantage.

item.title: Soccer Still Has Some Explaining to Do
item.description: Re-read today, Franklin Foer’s 2004 classic inadvertently suggests where globalization went wrong.

item.title: Bangladesh’s Pivotal Election and Referendum Has a Date. Will Unrest Follow?
item.description: The stakes are high for Bangladesh's first election since the 2024 student-led uprising.

item.title: A Tale of Two Asylum-Seekers
item.description: “Souleymane’s Story” interrogates the fictions we tell ourselves about what makes an acceptable migrant.

item.title: What to Make of North Korea’s End-of-Year Party Plenum
item.description: The plenum served as a primer for the bigger party congress that is yet to come.

item.title: A New Framework for Financing Global Security
item.description: Rather than improving global security, surging military expenditure threatens to deepen geopolitical instability, destroy ecosystems, fuel arms races, raise conflict risks, and crowd out public investment in other priorities, not least development aid. It doesn't have to be this way.

item.title: America’s Pharmaceutical Dependence on China Is a National Security Crisis
item.description: China controls a staggering portion of the United States’ pharmaceutical supply chain – and that means U.S. access to medicine can be weaponized.

item.title: Trump’s Immigration Crackdown Isn't Working
item.description: Some right-wing political leaders view Donald Trump’s immigration crackdown as a model to emulate. But a closer look at the numbers confirms that, while denouncing foreigners can be politically fruitful, attempting to get rid of them is both economically costly and demonstrably futile.

item.title: Russia Sees the Former Soviet Union as a ‘Fiefdom,’ Moldova’s Foreign Minister Says
item.description: The foreign minister also said if anyone can bring peace to the region, it’s U.S. President Donald Trump.

item.title: China’s ‘Low-Human-Rights’ Advantage
item.description: People in the West say they must avoid a new Cold War without realizing that they are already in one – and China is winning.

item.title: Cover Story: newsletter Can anyone stop Europe’s populist right?
item.description: An exclusive look at how we designed our cover

item.title: Are some types of sugar healthier than others?
item.description: We weigh up the options

item.title: U.S. Diplomats Take Trump to Court Over Mass Firings
item.description: The U.S. Foreign Service officers union seeks an injunction to prevent nearly 250 terminations.

item.title: Germany Loves to Hate Friedrich Merz
item.description: Germany’s chancellor is doing far better than everyone seems to think.

item.title: Benin’s Failed Coup and the Future of African Democracy
item.description: The recent explosion of coups and coup plots in West Africa, most recently in Benin, suggests that the region's performative approach to Western-style democracy is running out of steam. While democracy itself is not dead, the continent most likely is heading toward more varied forms of political organization.

item.title: Should China Be Reassured by Trump’s National Security Strategy?
item.description: The NSS is likely to offer China short-term relief – but cause for long-term concern.

item.title: Will the EU’s Blacklisting of Russia Make a Difference?
item.description: The European Commission has finally added Russia to its list of “high-risk” third countries with strategic deficiencies in their anti-money laundering and counter-terrorist financing controls. This blunt measure will close certain loopholes while also imposing collateral damage on innocent Russians.

item.title: Chinese Electric Buses Are Thriving in Europe – Despite Security and Forced Labor Concerns
item.description: Chinese electric bus manufacturers are using their membership in the U.N. Global Compact to deflect scrutiny from European regulators.

item.title: Pakistan’s 27th Amendment Upends Its Nuclear Command
item.description: A constitutional reform throws restraint, deterrence, and regional stability into question.

item.title: How Chinese Analysts Interpret Trump’s 2025 National Security Strategy
item.description: Far from celebrating an American retreat, Beijing’s strategists are reading the NSS as a blueprint for leaner – and potentially more dangerous – U.S. primacy.

item.title: Will Nepal’s September Uprising Transform the Ballot?
item.description: The elections set for March 2026 will test whether the political energy unleashed by the youth uprising can truly break free from transactional politics.

item.title: Donald Trump Is Unaffordable
item.description: There is every reason to think that US President Donald Trump will not have solved his affordability problem by the time voters head to the polls for next year's midterm elections. After all, his entire economic agenda seems designed to make things worse.

item.title: France and Mauritius: Strengthening Ties in the Indian Ocean
item.description: With major powers like China and India asserting their ambitions in the Indian Ocean, France relies on partnerships with like-minded countries, including Mauritius, to maintain its influence.

item.title: Omar García Harfuch, Mexico’s “Batman” with big political ambitions
item.description: The country’s best security minister in years must contend with drug cartels, Donald Trump and assassins’ bullets

item.title: AUKUS After AUSMIN: Why Canberra Must Read Washington Clearly
item.description: Washington’s political message remains supportive, but its strategic priorities no longer clearly align with the long-term demands of the partnership.

item.title: Will Japan’s First Woman Prime Minister Finally Tackle Violence Against Women?
item.description: How Takaichi's government addresses the implementation gap for existing laws will define whether her historic appointment translates into substantive progress for women's safety.

item.title: The Welfare State Saved Capitalism. Now It Can Save European Democracy.
item.description: A growing skepticism of social spending risks undermining a post-war pillar of Europe’s stability.

item.title: Starmer Acknowledges Britain’s China Problem But Overestimates the UK’s Ability to Fix It
item.description: The real problem is not Britain’s lack of engagement with Beijing, but its shrinking leverage in a China-U.S. power dynamic that London has no power to shape.

item.title: Land Degradation and Tajikistan’s Food Security Crisis
item.description: The country's small, fragmented farms and climate pressures threaten food security and economic stability.

item.title: USMCA Deal Comes up for Review
item.description: Trump has kept Canada and Mexico guessing about whether he will renew the trade agreement.

item.title: What’s Really Changed in ‘New Uzbekistan’?
item.description: Since the 2016 death of the country’s first president, Islam Karimov, his successor, Shavkat Mirziyoyev, has strived to present himself as a reformer forging a “New Uzbekistan."

item.title: The Far Right’s Gender Playbook
item.description: Around the world, authoritarian leaders are weaponizing gender-based grievances to rally supporters and roll back women’s and LGBTQ+ rights. By casting feminism as a threat to “family stability” and the “moral order,” they seek to shift public sentiment toward a patriarchal, illiberal future.

item.title: Ten Years After the Paris Agreement, Let’s Redouble Efforts
item.description: It is exactly a decade since 195 countries made a historic commitment to work together to keep the long-term rise in global temperatures well below 2°C above pre-industrial levels. Since then, France has fully embraced a leadership role, placing ecology at the heart of its energy, agricultural, and industrial policies.

item.title: An American oil blockade would devastate the Venezuelan regime
item.description: The gangsters who prop up Nicolás Maduro rely heavily on money from oil exports

item.title: Afghanistan’s Uncertain Gamble for Economic Survival
item.description: A struggling regime is caught between countervailing forces.

item.title: Accountability for Nepal’s China-built Pokhara Airport Has Begun
item.description: Nepal's anti-corruption watchdog has filed a corruption case against 55 individuals and a Chinese company in relation to the construction of the $216 million airport.

item.title: How Europe Lost
item.description: Can the continent escape its Trump trap?

item.title: The Multipolar Mirage
item.description: Why America and China are the world's only great powers.

item.title: Thai Prime Minister Gains Royal Approval For Dissolution of Parliament
item.description: The move, which Anutin Charnvirakul said would "return power to the people," will pave the way for a snap election in late January or early February.

item.title: Why North Korea is modernising its conventional arsenal
item.description: Russia's war economy is fuelling Pyongyang's most ambitious military upgrade in decades.
